body:
basically I think almost all of the extra deps are unnecessary which could mean <1MiB overhead in terms of jar size for a pretty sweet feature even if we start by turning it off by default.

We have had some grumbles about how our recent jar hike (prior to this) is slowing people with wan connections, so hoping we can just obviate that.

Shoot, that's right.  The Semaphore is technically pre-enqueue so it is on the ingestion thread which would block sending a response.  Didn't think about that earlier :(

FWIW, I'm testing my changes for #2481 in our production environment soon.  Still no ETA on when I'll make a pull request and certainly no promises on it being acceptable.  Plus there is some Apache stuff to work through now.  But I'll try to stay on top of it :)
@Logic-32 thanks for the status update and keep up the good work. This change has needed a champion for a while and I'm glad you are considering all angles mentioned!

This is the internet, not a job interview :P  No offense of course; if there is strong motivation to change I can :)

I've seen the plans for moving to ASF but haven't been following it.  Would it be acceptable to open/review a pull request before filling that out?  Hate to go through the effort of signing up for that if my work doesn't make the cut ;)

Also, while I'm here, one issue that will come up in the review is that of overriding other settings.  Is there any precedent for, say, having a "global" max-concurrency setting which would override [zipkin.storage.elasticsearch.max-requests](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/38d2148b914329c7ad0bbe45457e1969c6383797/zipkin-server/src/main/resources/zipkin-server-shared.yml#L105) for instance?  I see there are other "max-active" and like settings.  If we're going to have something that controls how many items get access to storage at a given instant then it makes sense that the settings for them remain in sync.  Though, there is certainly no obligation to do so.  Thoughts/opinions?

The way you are working so far, I don't anticipate nothing will change in
the code here.

> Also, while I'm here, one issue that will come up in the review is that of

> "global" max-concurrency setting which would override
> zipkin.storage.elasticsearch.max-requests

> for instance? I see there are other "max-active" and like settings. If
> we're going to have something that controls how many items get access to
> storage at a given instant then it makes sense that the settings for them
> remain in sync. Though, there is certainly no obligation to do so.
> Thoughts/opinions?
>
some people use spring cloud config or other tools for global
configuration. once (you can look in openzipkin-attic) we had a zookeeper
based sampler which provided a coordinated rate setting based on a group
membership. some things are not great to stick in the box but could be
supplied externally. For example, one project is downsampling to match
storage by using a buffer like voltdb which can easily absorb all the
traffic that it can fit in memory, allowing slower export to more rigid
storage. there will be some settings there that need coordination and we
might utilize the internal ZK for that
https://github.com/adriancole/zipkin-voltdb

Elasticsearch 7.0 has been released. 
Is there any workaround to change the index pattern zipkin uses?
@shakuzen Thanks for your reply! It's for performance and reliability.
@making it is not just an issue of the index naming convention. that's a very small matter actually. they've made significant changes to the index template itself
@adriancole so isn't ES 7.0 available until this issue is fixed?

@making this pull request needs to pass :) the index template needs to work and it doesn't on ES 7, so that's the main issue. When done debugging other things, I'll throw some time on this. It is good to know that ES 7 is final now.

there's actually another significant issue which is the revlock on the dependency aggregation job. To have dependencies link on ES 7 probably implies breaking ES 2.x https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-dependencies/issues/124 cc @openzipkin/elasticsearch
Do you continue to support ES 2x?

@making we've not yet unsupported it, so yeah we run tests on it on every build. I don't think we would want to un-support it at least until lens is default as otherwise people will revlock into the old UI.

amazon still lets people spin up 1.5! https://aws.amazon.com/elasticsearch-service/faqs/

Doing the following as mentioned [in our Quick Start instructions](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin#quick-start) worked for me:

```bash
curl -sSL https://zipkin.io/quickstart.sh | bash -s
java -jar zipkin.jar
```

Are you trying to use a custom zipkin-server-shared.yml file?
This kind of issue is easier to debug over chat. Join us on [our Gitter](https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin)

i run the following command

curl -sSL https://zipkin.io/quickstart.sh | bash -s
java -jar zipkin.jar

and then i got the same errors as above
i am not use a custom zipkin-server-shared.yml file
i just fetch the jar file,and then run the jar file,i do nothing othes.
the reason is the jdk version too old(1.8.0_20),upgrade the jdk version will resolve it.
@openzipkin/armeria anyone able to honor the spring compression setting in the armeria spring boot integration? seems best place to address the issue vs here.
It'd be nice if we could paginate the response if there are more than let's say 10k spans. It might be hard though to figure out a nice way to display that though

`armeria-spring-boot-webflux-autoconfigure` has the feature but `armeria-spring-boot-autoconfigure` doesn't.
https://github.com/line/armeria/blob/master/spring/boot-webflux-autoconfigure/src/main/java/com/linecorp/armeria/spring/web/reactive/ArmeriaReactiveWebServerFactory.java#L220-L251

We need to back port it to `armeria-spring-boot-autoconfigure` like what we did about ssl configuration, or you need to fix the zipkin code with the proposed fix.

@adriancole How much of spring is supposed to work with zipkin? I don't think Armeria should be reimplementing all of spring since it's reinventing the wheel. If most features of spring should work it's better to use the webflux integration so all features of spring work for free. My understanding when we migrated to pure armeria without using any bridge like tomcat or webflux was that zipkin-server doesn't need to have full support for spring features.
@anuraaga I think case-by-case and would guess that compression enabled might be one of those cases that is likely to be asked elsewhere even if asked here first. I might be wrong on that.

FWIW on this I agree it is a regression, but it was our fault for not having a test case. Because frameworks automatically do gzip we didn't put a test to cover it. We do have a number of issues raised about ensuring the POST endpoint accepts gzip, but this was a gap where we didn't explicitly test that the browser would get gzipped api response if asked.

as these sorts of issues tend to be re-hash in nature, and usually recreate content in various places, can we move parts of the discussion where some history exists?
* pagination or lack thereof to #2240
* UI presentation of large amounts of spans #1460 

We don't have any issue at the moment on mitigating based on span count at ingress (collection). I think this issue has new discussions on that point, and probably deserves to put mind on it.

some notes about the issue here.
* in-memory storage is explicitly mentioned as not for production. we have some other in-memory stuff cooking ex https://github.com/adriancole/zipkin-voltdb
* even if in-memory was ok, I don't know how many backends would work with (million-scale) traces.
* to the best of my knowledge we've not yet discussed span count based dropping at server level

I do think span count pruning has been discussed in brave, but there are issues about how that affects things. collector side would involve state to track it.. this is possible to do in single instance scenarios or where there are some shared state you can look up based on trace ID. I can see why someone would wonder about if we could special case this in the in-memory collector as we already have collections by trace ID.

PS for the last day and a half, I have been working on code to mitigate library conflicts between what we use in zipkin and zipkin-dependencies the spark job. I don't enjoy these sorts of conflicts.. yet I do them *ALL THE TIME*

when we decided to move to armeria it was in good faith that we could enjoy a certain amount of insulation from inflating those responsibilities even further. Please don't imply there's complete arbitrariness in our choice to not inflate our area of responsibility also into webflux in order to use armeria. I really want this topic to be open and shut. it is simply about compression and I doubt anyone would think that this is an edge case.

I don't think the decision to leave out webflux was arbitrary or even wrong, but just that it's not so clear how far the spring support in zipkin-server goes. So far there's been three spring features that didn't / don't work out of the box with armeria-spring, which is just to integrate spring DI with armeria servers, not to interface with spring itself

- actuator
- security
- compression

Spring is pretty huge, so I imagine more of these features could come up. webflux and Tomcat are the way armeria is able to interface with spring's huge ecosystem of features and it would be impractical to implement everything directly in armeria I think. Implementing compression is very easy, since it's just enabling a decorator based on a flag, so I don't think it's a problem to take care of it with armeria. Security would be much more complex and I would say probably too much? As long as we're clear that we'd treat them all case-by-case, and that zipkin-server does not intend to support the full Spring featureset, then we're on the same page.
@timothybasanov ps do you mind hopping on gitter for the load test related questions? I want to dig into them but not wander the issue too much https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin
I'm gonna put a patch together we can remove later. I think this is a big deal to fix.

@anuraaga eeek I may have lied a little.. here are the settings we explicitly mentioned. `use-forward-headers` is set and I'm not sure we test that.

```yaml
server:
  port: ${QUERY_PORT:9411}
  use-forward-headers: true
  compression:
    enabled: true
    # compresses any response over min-response-size (default is 2KiB)
    # Includes dynamic json content and large static assets from zipkin-ui
    mime-types: application/json,application/javascript,text/css,image/svg
```
verified the browser moves less bytes now..
cutting this shortly as I need to release a guava fix anyway

We probably can close this ticket (and related) as duplicates of one big ticket.
I'll try to talk on Gitter in more detail on what I'm doing locally with tests. :)

I think other tickets are slightly different from this one: they are about _slow_ UI, this one is about UI silently crashing with exceptions (overflow and/or browser crash) and server silently failing with exceptions (integer overflow). I don't expect Zipkin to work well with big traces, I just want it to not to crash.

I'd prefer to have tickets for individually solvable things even if there
is a big ticket with tickboxes. especially where existing tickets are
present.

this will help reduce a problems with the big ticket approach including.

* long winding discussions (tickets dont thread as well as email etc)
* rehashing incompletely discussions that already exist in a new place
* reduced approachability of doing anything as the work feels too big.

iotw please let's not close existing issues unless they are done or dupes
of older issues.

I am pretty sure there were other tickets that discussed what to do with
large traces. difference between 10k and 1M is a factor of that discussion.

however it is fine with me to repurpose this issue for too huge to load
traces. please dont close this as I dont want to require people to have to
look at two issues to get the discussion so far.

on this particular point of too big to load at all. there seem to be two ways about it if we are focusing on after the fact (UI) vs before (collection)

* we can identify based on size (easiest possibly a HEAD request)
* we can identify based on span count or some other trace scoped heuristic (engineering required if we want to stop browser from crashing reading the json)

while UI is primary user of api, it isn't the only user. so changing the API with special hooks is likely not worth doing. The api is not suited enough to retrofit to things like pagination quickly also. This issue is about preventing crashes so we can keep that in mind.

there are three entry points which this limiting concerns:

* trace list screen (one trace in results could be poison)
* trace by ID and trace by JSON (the only trace loaded could be poison big)

I can think of some remedies, and we have to remember this is different than the other issue about too big, but not too big to crash.

I think simple way out would be to just refuse to load when payload is larger than say 5MiB by default, with a setting one can update. I prefer size based as traces can be huge for other reasons not just span count like too many tags or annotations.

Another way that comes to mind is look at what tools exist for incremental parsing of json. cc @openzipkin/ui
opened #2498 on the in memory storage special casing though it wont work for other storage. rationale being that it is meant for testing so maybe we can improve the limiter

I found the two blockers on zipkin-dependencies. holding until they are sorted as it will not make sense to proceed here if we can't aggregate dependencies.

https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch-hadoop/issues/1277
https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch-hadoop/issues/1276
only task left is unit test sweep.. doing that now.
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/2499 will complete this change

I confirm SSL can be configured. However cipher suites and TLS version can not be tuned: https://github.com/line/armeria/issues/1711

Connecting Spring Security to Armeria and Zipkin looks very complicated, because Spring Security is based on Servlet API (or WebFlux API) contrary to Armeria.

we may not be able to support spring security.. something we never
supported anyway. it won't happen in this repo regardless.

we can put an example of basic auth configuration in a unit test that does
not use spring security.

The [SAML SSO](https://line.github.io/armeria/advanced-saml.html) is another interesting lead.

Using a reverse proxy to do security is not good solution in our case because despite firewalls Zipkin would still be exposed in some way.

How can I add security related Armeria decorators to Zipkin HTTP services? Can you see an easy and cross-cutting extension point?

Attaching some very early results of running my changes in production (wanted to make sure these were up in time for the LINE workshop).

Before:
![before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25107222/56247242-625f0780-6061-11e9-82ed-eff6afe1b8cb.png)

After:
![after](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25107222/56247247-64c16180-6061-11e9-9892-0d67109fe7ba.png)

Results are 24 hours apart.  New metrics:
- Throttle concurrency/limit = how many Threads Netflix thinks we can run
- Throttle in flight requests = concurrency + queue size; should be the same most of the time but is mostly just a check to make sure we're resolving all our LimitListeners and not leaking anything.

You can see the Drop Rate spikes are not only fewer farther apart but thinner with no appreciable impact on Response Times or Heap.

awesome job

I don't think a change around this would occur in this repository
I think we have example of how to do this now

Instead of debating which character to use when building index names. What about making it configurable and let the developer choose the index pattern (with sensible defaults). In Logstash you can configure `logstash-%{type}-%{+YYYY.MM.dd}` for instance, it's very convenient, and it can be backward compatible. Even with Elasticsearch 6.x I'd like to drop the colon from index name, in order to ease upgrade to Elasticsearch 7.x.

About index templates, and mappings in particular, instead of trying to build a generic and complicated `VersionSpecificTemplates` class which can handle all versions. What about just having a template file for each version like in Logstash (in https://github.com/logstash-plugins/logstash-output-elasticsearch/tree/master/lib/logstash/outputs/elasticsearch see elasticsearch-template-*.json).

the major issue is not the delimiter, it is the index template change

we can't currently reproduce this in either UI. perhaps recently we fixed it
right now, people usually use lower-hyphen in case format, btw

since changing this will impact several things, we need buy-in to do that (and time to address the concerns this would create also). For now, I'm closing this issue, but we can re-open it if things change.

I created an example project to show how someone can do this. usual disclaimers apply.. if someone makes a custom integration, that will eventually need maintenance when we upgrade to spring boot 3 or some new version of a library etc. https://github.com/adriancole/zipkin-security
thanks for the advice @xeraa
related https://github.com/apache/incubator-zipkin/issues/2496
this only happens in "zipkin classic" which will be deleted soon. I checked and lens does not have this problem. Closing this as won't fix because we have to conserve energy. Thanks for reporting!

I would also note that if you are using the latest version of the Zipkin Server, you can switch to the new Zipkin Lens UI with the "Try Lens UI" button near the top right of the UI. This would avoid the issue reported, as Adrian mentioned.

I will close this issue because the new UI Zipkin Lens does not have the bug and we will soon delete the api that has the bug. Please try zipkin lens so that when we do delete the old UI you have the features you need.
lens right now has a drop under which doesn't seem to lose place in the trace list as it is easy to undo it. I'll reopen this issue if folks feel it isn't working.
duplicate of #2417

so we should think about the default policy for formatting big text and the use cases where it would be big. Usually this is request/response tags like SQL query and it may well be the best to not wrap these data.

lens currently wraps
I think this is fixed in lens now
@lambcode can you try latest zipkin with the lens UI and raise an issue for any glitches? we will close this issue as the zoom was rewritten as a minimap
By the way, I filed https://github.com/line/armeria/issues/1725 since I think it's good for the redirect to make it easy or default to preserving query
this is done in lens now as all choices are validated. we aren't fixing anything more in classic at this point
This is related to the i18n library we use. We don't have cycles to address this in the classic UI. Lens might not use the same library in #2487
we aren't going to do any more npm wrangling in the classic UI. AFAICT Lens is fine

Seems that this is caused when escape characters are present (e.g. \t or \n). When there is a long tag value without these it works fine.

For instance, this tag is shown with the bug: https://github.com/apache/incubator-zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-ui/testdata/smartthings-oauth-authorization.json#L110

But this one https://github.com/apache/incubator-zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-ui/testdata/smartthings-oauth-authorization.json#L3010 works fine.

Replacing `"\n` and `\n"` with `"` and `\n` and `\t` with ` ` might be a way to solve this.
we are iceboxing this. maybe after we work on grafana, we will have more experience in how plugin systems work. This doesn't mean we'll have the ability or time to recreate this sort of framework.
we are not fixing this in classic zipkin. lens will likely use a different library in #2487
As @adriancole mentioned, this bug is not present on Lens UI.
closed moving high-cardinality support to #2506

Associating the delimiter change to ES version change is not a good thing to me https://github.com/apache/incubator-zipkin/blob/6a3b6446f011bacf497b0860f4a5c7cce3f7ae85/zipkin-storage/elasticsearch/src/main/java/zipkin2/elasticsearch/IndexTemplates.java#L38
I am beginning with Zipkin+ES6 now, if I can change the delimiter now, the ES7 upgrade will be smoother.
please ask us to reopen this if what happens in #2507 misses the mark
Let's do Newest with a cookie in Lens. In the "notable" section of to be written docs about lens vs classic, we should mention that newest has disadvantages mentioned here.
we won't fix this in classic, but we'll keep watch in #2509 for lens
we won't address this i18n library in classic #2487 will likely use a different library in lens
in lens, color shading is used to show client+server timing of a span. we aren't investing any more time in the classic UI
the logic has been completely written and so has the UI, so it might be easier to notice any new problem vs think through what's changed

one note relevant here is that lens allows multiple spans to be expanded which compensates somewhat for usability concerns on client and server spans that don't share an ID. I'm not sure it is worse than other tools like jaeger or stackdriver in this regard or not.
duplicate of #2488
this is done in lens now (with shading and inspired by @rogeralsing's work)

let's make sure there's a tooltip on the sort button to help reduce the amount of frustration people have when they expect the api to sort according to the client-side sort (#1218)

it will take some time to get the text right.

we are switching the order to newest first which matches the server-side ordering #1926

however, we'll still have people surprised that we can't arbitrarily sort in all backends by fields such as duration. That's not something we have any good alternatives to, so we will try to address this in docs in #2488
closing as lens renders the trace completely differently and we aren't investing any more effort in the classic ui
#2488 will add some clarifications also
lens uses a different library for the service graph and we aren't investing any more effort in classic UI
the dependency graph has been rewritten completely in lens so closing out issues in the classic ui
